cd.definition: This command is used to change directory.
cd.usage_1: If we type cd 'path'. It will go to the defined path by the user.
cd.usage_2: If the user types 'cd ../' It will go to the previous dir.
cd.example_1: cd Downloads' The directory will change to Downloads
cd.example_2: cd ../'The directory will go to the previous dir. C://(here)

echo.definition: definition = This command will repeat the user input
echo.usage: echo 'message'. The output will be the message typed.
echo.example: echo Hello. The output will be Hello.

mkdir.usage: mkdir 'name'. Here it will create a directory named the name given by the user
mkdir.example: mkdir Test. Here it will create a directory named Test

rmdir.usage: rmdir 'name od dir'. Here it will delete the directory which is selected by the user
rmdir.example: 'rmdir Test'. Here it will delete the directory selected

create.definition: This command is used to create files in the selected dir
create.usage: create 'name(with ext)'. Here it will create a file in the cwd(current working directory) name given in the user input
create.example: 'create file.txt'. Here it will create a file named file.txt on the cwd

rm.definition: This command remove the selected file in the cwd(current working directory)
rm.usage: rm 'name(withext)'. Here it will delete this file
rm.example: 'rm file.txt'. Here it will delete this file.txt

search.definition: This command searches for an existing file in the cwd(current working directory)
search.usage: search 'name(with ext)'. Here it shows the path of the searched file
search.example: 'search file.txt'. Here it shows the path of the file 'file.txt'

ls.definition: This commands shows the list of files in cwd(current working directory)
ls.usage: 'ls'. It shows all the files and folders in the cwd(current workinf directory)
ls.example: 'ls'. This shows the list of files and folders in cwd(current working directory)
